In April of 1868, farmer Dawson Pompey, nearly 70, reputed to be the son of a slave and her master, set off to make history.
For reasons only he may have known, he decided to run for public office.
He wanted to be a highway overseer in the Covert Township, where roads were raw and hacked through the forest.
Now, it was illegal for a black man to vote in Michigan, much less stand for office.
Near Detroit, not very long before, a man just one-sixteenth black was arrested for merely attempting to vote.
But in Covert, dozens of white men raised their hands in the air - or perhaps, raised their voices - to elect Dawson Pompey a highway overseer.
